plist.p: .MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION

Welcome. Welcome to all of you and thank you very much for joining us today. I will just introduce the presentation with a few words on the way we are managing our Bank through the crisis and on the way we hope we will have our Bank emerging from this crisis even stronger than it is today. First point, we are bringing to you an almost €4 billion worth of results before impairment. It's in our opinion a good evidence of the resilience of our business model of our business system. It's a business model you know very well. It's focused on retail in especially one country, our country Italy. Three-fourth of our revenues come from this market. We believe this market has still a lot of attractiveness, a lot of opportunities to be exploited and we have the leading position, the coverage of the market that will put us in the position to exploit such opportunities.

So the first point was the four billion in terms of pre-impairment net income. Impairment policy, we have decided to be very prudent, we have decided to do all the impossible impairments because we believe that this is the right way to manage a situation like the one we are presently living. There is an idiom in – a way to say in Italian and that – and what we have done is we have put some extra hay in the barn because we do not know how long it will last the winter. So it is a way to translate what we say in Italian, but that was exactly what we had in mind in preparing our 2008 accounts.

Two – a couple of real strength of our Bank. First one is the liquidity position. We believe liquidity is a key factor for success, will remain a key factor for success. We have decided to create a very strong position. As you know, as you probably saw in the presentation, we are amongst the very few banks with a net interbank balance. We have created it during the last 18 months and we are defending it. At the same time, we have accumulated on the side about more than 50 billion worth of eligible assets. We want to be the liquid bank. We don't want to have any surprise. We want to be able to meet the commitment and the engagements we have taken and liquidity will be one of our key competitive strengths.

Second has to do with capital ratios. After the decision we have taken about the Tremonti Bonds and I will elaborate on that point. We are in a very strong, definitely strong position from the capital ratios point of view. Actually, from the point of view of, in my opinion, the most important ratio in terms of capital ratios, we are the best in Europe. And the capital ratios I have in mind is the ratio between tangible equity and tangible asset. At the end what really matters is tangible equity and what really matters is tangible assets. If you make debt ratio and you compare Intesa Sanpaolo with any of its peers you see our Bank is well placed, number one and will remain number one.

So why the Tremonti Bonds, why the four billion? Because we believe it's safe and it is wise to have a short-term insurance policy in a situation like this one. I think that the terms and conditions at which this capital facility, this equity facility is now being offered to all the Italian banks is fair, is good, is a set of good terms and conditions. It's flexible because we can give it back any time we want and in the first four years it will be without any premium any penalty in terms of the repayment – in terms of repayment and there is no dilution in terms of out – the number of shares for our shareholders. So we believe that it was the right thing to do in a situation like this one and that we as you will see from the presentation we want to give it back as soon as possible, but since the winter I mentioned before will last for a period we do not know, it's a – it was a wise decision to buy this sort of insurance policy in favor of our banks – of our Bank, of our shareholders and of our customers.

Two areas of known concern, the first one has to do with the provision policy on our lending activity. We have been very careful, we have been very prudent and the figures coming from this year 2000 and year the first figures of this year are the evidence of it. We have made a very strong provision at the end of last year and in fact in the first two months of 2009 the flow of the new doubtful loans, of new substandard loans is for the time being significantly lower than what it used to be at the end of last year. That doesn't mean anything because it's only two months and that we expect in 2009 to have higher provisions obviously than in 2008, but I wanted to just convey the massage that we have tried to be as prudent as possible also in that respect.

The second area of known concern is our presence in Central-Eastern Europe. It's a strong network. It's a network of 10 banks, very well placed, very well managed and it contributes to our results and there are over 10% and in terms of assets is in the round of 7% of our assets. But 7% subdivided into 10 countries gives you the reason why we are not at all worried. We are not at all worried because we believe in those banks and we believe in the way they are managed. But in any case, there is no single case that can create any sort of concern to the overall stability and strength of our Group.

2009. 2009 will be as you say, as people say, very challenging, I confirm it. We try to get as ready as possible for this challenge and the accounts and the way we have made 2008 accounts is in line with this expectation. We expect solid, strong, say solid profits for next year, and we are hopeful we will be able to get back to dividend payment and have just one year of interruption in our dividend payment.

We are quite hopeful. We are quite sure about what I'm saying because as far as the interest margin is concerned, we are managing this environment on the asset side with a very strict and strong spread defense activity. On the deposit side, we have then in advance, a number of good choices in terms of hedging, to this hedging part of our structural deposit base. So that will help us to have a decrease in interest margin next year because it's unavoidable but reasonably low one.

In terms of cost, we will have another minus year. We will have another strong performance in terms of cost reduction. As far as provision, I already mentioned what we have done in like last quarter. And maybe I can spend one word on trading profit. Trading profit reached their peak last year especially in the fourth quarter because we have decided to make a lot of provision there too, and that we have already taken into account the volatility of the first quarter 2009 in defining the evaluations on our trading portfolio at the end of 2008. And this decision will certainly make the performance of our trading line easier next year.

Last point is about the overall reaction of our Bank. And let me tell you that it's a real pleasure, it's an honor, it's a real pleasure to be with the team of people I have around me. The kind of reaction I see throughout the organization is quite effective. The cohesiveness, not only the quality of the people that are managing the Bank is superb and that's the main reason why we see, we look at the future with an high level of optimism. At the same time, as you know we have introduced some further simplification and some further strengthening of our Banca dei Territori, the retail network organization. These changes have been very well received by our people, and completing the first tour around Italy, because I wanted to meet all the 8,000 middle managers we have in the field, and I really got the impression that we have taken a number of right decisions to make their job easier and more effective.

Last point, investments. We never stopped our investments. All the investments provided for in the business plan have been completed. 2008 has the full amount of investments, innovation, human capital, long-term kind of investments. 2009 will have another important portion of investments because we want – we tend to manage with a long-term view and that will not change only because of the strong but at the end contingent crisis we are living throughout the world.

So these were the main points. Now we will go through the presentation and I will go quite rapidly through the pages because they are more than the needed to give you the impression of the way we are managing the company. And then we will have all the time that is needed for the questions.

These are the main points I mentioned before. The core profitability of the Bank, we will see those figure more in detail. The strength of the domestic retail market and why we believe in our domestic markets. The liquidity profile that is one – probably the strongest strength of the Group, the risk profile, very low leverage, that's another important point. Almost best-in-class also from the leverage point of view and certainly adequate capital strength.

3.9 billion adjusted net income in fiscal year 2008. When we say adjusted, we mean for non-recurring items and bulk of these non-recurrent items are the impairments we've done on intangibles, on goodwill, on participations. 3.1 billion worth of impairment of equity investments goodwill and other intangibles only partially offset by 1.6 billion goodwill. So there are some extraordinary good news that partially compensate for the negative extraordinary items, but the net effect of the 3.1 and the 1.6 is net 1.5 billion, that flows entirely into the fourth quarter and brings the fourth quarter to minus 1.2 but that's all accounting, that's impairment. In fact, the tangible net equity during the last quarter has increased by 200 million. So that's the evidence of the fact that we are not talking of about, let me use the word real losses, but accounting losses. So the bottom line as stated is 2.5, and also the bottom line of the fourth quarter if we adjust it for the non-recurrent items is more than 350 million.

Our business model, mainly concentrated in retail in Italy, very important role played by our International Subsidiary Division, we will talk about it and by our Corporate and Investment Banking Division that is area of asset of the Group. This is only to remember that on this market at this point we have – this market, I mean the Italian retail market in a real strong position. And when you build a leading position, you benefit from it from a structural point of view. And this leading position is getting stronger and stronger year after year.

Liquidity profile, excellent. Direct customer deposits higher than loans to customer, here is the reason why we feel comfortable. But even more than that these three evidences, first, one of the few banks with a positive balance on the interbank market. You might remember that we have built it quarter-after-quarter in the last five quarters.

Second, a very strong amount – a very large amount of eligible assets with Central Banks, 56 billion. Obviously these two decisions have a cost, you find part of this cost on the interest income because if you want to have a positive position here, you don't leverage on that kind of activity. If you want to have a portfolio of reserve assets, then you pay some cost of it but it's well within what we can afford.

This is another very important point. Funding needs, long-term funding needs for 2009, if you compare this figure with what we have placed as a retail network during 2008, you see that we can do by ourselves the old job. Even if the interbank market, even if the international cash funding market becomes unavailable, we can easily cope with those needs with our own placing capabilities. And in fact, in the first two months of 2009, 12 billion have already been raised. So if you make this figure six times, you'll see that you more than cover the amount that is needed to match the long-term funding needs of the Bank.

I mentioned, the very prudent provision policy we followed in at the end of last year, more than 100 basis points. I think it was a good decision given the situation. We see a concentration of the sub-optimal credit assets in the typical industries where that are mostly hit, immediately hit by the recession but that's absolutely forecastable. What is an encouraging sign is that in looking at the flow, the monthly flow of new substandard and doubtful loans in the first two months of the year, you'll see that they are much lower than they used to be last year and they used to be in the last quarter of 2008. Again I'm not saying that provisions will decrease next year. Provisions on our loan portfolio will increase. But what I'm saying is that we probably did very well our job at the end in the fourth quarter.

Another evidence of a prudent approach by ourselves, our separate, our doubtful loans are over covered if I can use this word because if we take guarantees, other collateral kind of support and we add the specific coverage, that the coverage we give, we accumulate every year, we get to a figure that is certainly higher than 100%.

Don't look at the figure but we wanted to give you all the figures. This is the situation in Central-Eastern Europe. And you see that, and for each country, you have all the details. All together, the customer loans of all the total region, Central-Eastern Europe accounts for 7% and by, for example Ukraine is 0.1%. We wanted to give you these figures because you have to know what the situation is, and certainly that there is no case, no country can in itself create any sort of concern for the Group as a whole. But more than that, we are giving you all the details in terms of loans, in terms of loans in local currency and in foreign currency, in each of the country all the figures that can put you in the position to make a complete evaluation of our situation in each country.

One point that I want to stress is this one, direct customer deposits in foreign currency are higher than foreign currency retail loans. So even if the amount of loans in foreign currency is a significant figure, given the small size of the , we are to a large extent covered by the availability of direct customer deposits in foreign currency.

Our doubtful loans are very well – sorry I pushed the wrong button – very well covered throughout the region. And the same way we have used, you remember when the problem with the structured credit products came on the table, we said we'll give you all the details, you decide. You will find all the details about our structured credit product portfolio also in this presentation. But since the anxiety about this region of the world was – is growing in a number of other situations, we decided to give you all the details to put you in the position to evaluate what we are doing.

Leverage, if you take it from the economic point of view, total assets over operating margins, if you take it from the capital point of view and you put tangible assets on tangible net equity, you see that the position of our Bank is quite strong. Actually if you reverse this ratio and you'll create the capital ratio I mentioned before, that means tangible net shareholders equity over tangible total assets that in my opinion, I want to repeat this point, is the real ratio to measure the capital ratio of the Bank you see that our Bank is in a good position.

Capital ratio, the traditional ones. We closed the year with 6.3, 7.1, 10.2. Then we have a number of disposals that had already been completed and decided and the effect of the Tremonti Bonds. One comes from Tremonti and the other one comes from the disposals. So we present ourselves with 7.4, 8.2 and 11.3. What these bowl says? These cloud, let's say, says that we had a reserve in terms of non-core asset that will be disposed one day in the round of 150 basis point book value. One of the reasons why we have not sold them today is because we would get only the book value, while some of these assets had quite a higher, bigger value.

This was part of the business plan you might remember. We have this reserve. We are working on all these assets because one day it might become a very important source of capital gains, of capital ratios and of liquidity. We are not forcing these says and certainly not even listing of some of these companies because as you know, this is not the right time to do it. But never forget that this is something we have as a further reserve for financing our growth.

The Board today has confirmed the decision not to pay dividend. It's very consistent with the prudent approach I mentioned before to distribute what is provided for in favor of the saving shares and to buy an insurance policy, the Tremonti Bonds I mentioned before. These are the – all the features, the characteristics, the terms and conditions of the Tremonti Bonds. We can get back to these points if you are interested. One point I want to stress is brevity. We are using this insurance policy for the shorter possible period. As soon as the situation gets back to normality, these bonds will be repaid.

Outlook 2009, something I have already said before. We are quite confident we will be able to defend our spreads, and to benefit from the hedging activities with from hedging decisions we have taken in the last 12 months. So, we expect a decline in net interest income that's almost unavoidable but a decline that will be in this area mid-single digit.

Cost reduction, further cost reductions because we are now completing the integration and completing the projects coming from the integration of the two banks and that create synergies. As I said, net adjustment, that means provisions on loans will be higher, but first evidence in the year are encouraging in that respect, and we don't expect further substantial impairment because we've been very prudent in 2008.

Okay. We are preparing also the business plan, the new business plan. By the end of December, we are confident we will be able to provide you with this plan. We are waiting for the economic forecast to settle down and to become a little bit more reliable. We expect a difficult 2009, a difficult 2010, and then the history starts again in 2011. Maybe we are too pessimistic, but it's always better to get ready for the worst.

Especially in the third year, revenues will have a good growth. Costs will keep going down and they will have a minus sign vis-à-vis 2008 level. Asset quality will remain a priority, liquidity will remain a competitive strength, and then we will probably have at least part, maybe all, the effect of the capital actions we might take on this 10 billion book value kind -- amount of assets that might become a much bigger figure.

Progressive pay-out means that year-after-year we expect the dividend pay-out to grow, as it used to be. Obviously our dividend pay-out will be defined in such a way to maintain capital strength, obviously. We want to remain at the very top of the rank in terms of tangible equity to tangible asset ratio, and the reasons I – we discussed them before, and we will be very – we will do our best in order to use Pillar II and Pillar II to optimize our capital requirements.

2008. Again, some more detail on 2008. We have already mentioned most of this figure. Operating margin up 6.7, operating cost down 3.3. Asset quality, something I have not mentioned before, we have a strong generic reserve on performing loans. This amount is bigger than the expected loss, and that's another reserve we have in the balance sheet. Strict asset revaluation policy applied means that we have done all the possible impairments that were available. And we have also added almost 200 million worth of conservative valuation on structured credit products in the last quarter. The number of customers in the retail division has increased during the year by a reasonable figure. And we have completed, ahead of schedule, all the IT merger of the two banks.

This is our balance sheet. Loans to customer, good figure. Financial assets decreased, mostly because of the four months' effect here in indirect customer deposits while direct customer deposits show a very satisfactory growth.

The P&L. Net interest income up 12.2%. These three columns, in order to put in the position to make all the relevant comparison, the first column is the comparison between the two stated P&L. Then this column takes away – takes out the non-recurrent items, especially the impairments, and this last column eliminate also the trading profit -- trading loss, actually, in order to have a feeling of the industrial performance of the Bank. And in fact, if you take away the bad year from the trading point of view, you'll see that also from the operating income we have a positive figure. We believe is good to have this kind of trend in terms of cost control, and this figure in terms of operating margin.

From this line downward, we have all the effect of the goodwill impairment, more than 1 billion, then we have the increase of almost 1 billion in terms of loan provisions. We have the other impairments, almost 1 billion here, and we have here the last extraordinary effect of the 1 billion that brings everything to 2.5 billion. The 7.250 [billion] -- you remember we had almost 3 billion worth of capital gains for the disposals we had in 2007. I will not elaborate on this one, but you will find after each table, after each set of figures, all the details in order for you to understand what we mean by adjusted, what we consider non-recurrent, what we consider comparable or not comparable, because the P&L and the balance sheets of banks that keep changing also in terms of perimeter is not an easy task, and we try to make this task as easy as possible.

Last quarter, 353 million in terms of net income, if we exclude the impairment, and we get almost to 450 if we also exclude the trading profit. Most of these point have already been commented before. This is the last quarter of last year, certainly a decrease not unexpected, and then all the big effect of the impairment policy. And here the detail in order to put you in the position to understand the different comparisons.

Net interest income, we believe it's a good figure at a yearly level. The trend is not surprising because interest rates and interest margins have decreased in the last part of the year, and again we have decided to keep our interbank position at the level we have it and that as a cost as well as the cost of keeping a certain amount of eligible assets. In terms of growth, here we see the percentage growth in the different segments of the company and the growth in terms of volumes in absolute terms. We have clearly supported the growth of the economies in the countries where we operate but we have been careful because the quality, the risk profile of our loan portfolio is let me tell you almost priority number one in order to keep a very safe flow of results. We will make any comment afterwards.

Here we have the figure to explain the change in net interest income in the last quarter. Volumes accounted for growth, spread further decrease and here is the effect of the decreased volume of financial activities that have decreased the total amount of our interest income.

Fee and commission down and we expect the 2009 to be another weak year. And all the banking, and all the commercial banking activities more or less are even where we have lost a very significant amount of money within the area of asset management and consultancy activity, minus 20%. Here is the area of concern but is also the area of potential growth of opportunity for the next years.

We are investing. We are putting the right people in this area. We are not happy yet about what we are providing our customers with, but as you know, it's very difficult and this industry is suffering everywhere in the world. What we're doing might put us into position to benefit from the starting of the growth again in at the end of this year or the beginning we hope of next year. This point is important because if we look at asset under management, we see a very bad figure, but this money has not left the bank. These customers have not left the bank. They have simply switched to other ways to use the bank with their money, most of the money has gone to asset under administration and that quite an amount of money has become direct customer deposits. At the end, during the year, the net flows of retail customer financial asset is a positive figure. This is very important because as soon as the environment changes, and as soon we are good enough to offer the right products, these assets are there waiting for the right way to be serviced.

Trading profits from 1.2 billion to zero, and especially the last quarter has been the bad one. But here you have the 184 million that has to do with the volatility we expect in the first quarter of 2009. So part of this loss, that is not the real loss but it's an accounting loss, so it's a loss has to do with the very prudent policy we have decided to take in the last quarter of last year.

The details, in order for you to understand how this figure is created. Customer related activity not that high but not strange given the situation. Capital market still low but will grow. Prop trading and treasury negative and that has especially to do with the devaluations on the portfolio of government bonds we have as eligible assets, and that we decided to accept as a sort of cost of insurance. And this is the effect on our structured credit products. Half of it, a bit more than half has to do with first quarter 2009, the rest has to do with last quarter, last year. All the details about the structured credit product portfolio are in the presentation. Their portfolio is going down. We are succeeding in reducing it little-by-little. At the end, we don't expect to have real losses on the, the very large majority of these assets. And all the details are in the annexes to the presentation.

Cost very much under control. All operating cost and especially the personnel expenses. We have some growth as usual in the last quarter of the year but well under control. Total cost in Italy are almost or more than 5% down. This figure accounts for the effort we are doing and we have been doing last year in a number of Central, Eastern European countries to strengthen the retail network of branches.

Staff reduction, the yellow part is the one that will have to be realized in 2009. All these figures are connected with the trade agreements we have made with the unions. Three times we have discussed with them how to first get to the merger and then how to start the integration and now how to complete the integration. This part will be obviously done as planned in 2009.

When we say staff reduction, we must always remember that at the same time we have kept hiring people so that – that's the net effect but during the period we had more than 6,000 people hired in the bank. This table is only to give you – tell you that we are growing well below – well above in terms of target. So well below in terms of cost reduction and that was obviously due to the fact that the other components of our P&L, revenues in particular are not inline with the business plan. And this part of the page is to say that we are now getting to the total synergies that the plan provided for and that will be realized by the end of this year.
Cost income. Cost income is another rank where our Bank is not performing that bad.

Risk management policy, net provisions for risk and charges obviously lower than last year. Last year we had a couple of very extraordinary situations like the settlement with Parmalat, obviously higher than last year in terms of provisions on loans and especially the last two quarters have been very, very, very prudent.

Net doubtful loans are still in the round of 1%, so well under control. The coverage I already mentioned before. The reserve on performing loans I already mentioned it. So, I mean in the next three pages you have all the details about non-performing loans in the different divisions, in the different countries. You have the addition coming from any point of view. We have all the details to make a judgment on the way we are managing this part of the balance sheet.

Portfolio well diversified both in terms of business area and if we take the residential mortgages, that is the largest piece of the pie the risk profile keeps being very low. We are talking about an average situation where household's income account, the weight of servicing the mortgages is in the round of one-third the household's income. Loan to value is still in the round of 50%, and the average life of the mortgages is in the round of 20 years. In 25,000, 30,000 cases, we have agreed with our customers to make the duration longer to make them more sustainable by the households that has been done in the last two years and that has probably avoided problems for some of our customers.

In terms of breakdown of industry, you'll see it's quite a well diversified situation. You might have in your presentation a mistake because the last two lines were mixed and you might have in your presentation a 8% doubtful loans that is 1%, while loans on foreign banks is almost 9%, you might then the reverse. So, this is the right one.

I already mentioned this point. We got the foundation approach approved by the Bank of Italy and that brought us in the round of 15 or 13 or 15 basis points. You might ask a question about how much the cycle is embedded in these capital ratios and we can say that in the amount of the foundation after addition, almost 30% was kept aside for managing the profitability of the cycle, and we will have some further improvement available when the advanced Basel 2 will be approved.

Divisional figures, I will not go through the details. I'm obviously available to comment on all of them. We have all the divisions providing a positive EVA in 2007. Obviously, if you don't apply to them, the impairment figures but all the impairment are concentrated. At the center, we have all the details of the divisions.

2009, I already mentioned how we are going to manage the spread defense. I will be selective in terms of loan growth, how we will reduce costs, staff costs, other administrative costs and also amortization and depreciation already said. This is only to say that given the amount of impairment we had in 2008, we don't expect any significant further impairment in 2009 and conclusions are not surprising. The message is we think we got ready for the period we have in front of us. 2009 will be as I said a very challenging period. We count on a solid profit in 2009 and our capital position is now definitely secure and we expect and we hope to be able to get back to dividend payment already next year. This is the presentation and now we are all ready to answer your questions.
let's start from here if you agree. If there is anyone who wants to start then we will give the floor to our friends in the rest of the world.

Good morning. It's Riccardo Rovere from Mediobanca here. Two, three questions. The first one is on the provisions, I just wanted to better understand if the billion loan loss provisions you posted in Q4, if there is anything one-off? Because if I remember correctly you previously guided in the previous quarter anywhere between 500 and 600 million per quarter and this is the amount you posted in Q3 once I deduct Icelandic banks and Lehman from the number you released in Q3 850 million minus 250. The second question I have is on Tremonti Bonds, you stated before that you think the leverage ratio is the correct ratio you should look at to assess the capital or the equity of a bank, I agree on this. And this is the main reason why I am a bit confused, why you are asking 4 billion of Tremonti Bonds considering that this is not equity, this is kind of quasi equity that the Bank of Italy is allowing you to compute in quarter one but doesn't affect the equity at all. So I'm wondering why you're asking 4 billions. And just wanted to be 100% sure of the guidance you're giving for 2009. You are basically telling us that 2009 attributable profit will be lower than 2.5 billion which is the amount you posted in '08, just wanted to be sure I understood this correctly? Thanks.

First question about the total provisions in 2008, if I remember correctly our guidance was 60 basis points for the year. So, we are certainly above what we expected on the basis of the September results but and I think we are not at all far from the 60 basis points we had in mind as the maximum for 2008. In fact it was higher than we expected and – but we believe that adding and creating this cushion was a wise decision. Tremonti Bonds, Tremonti Bonds, so your question is why 4 billion or --

No, no, no, okay, okay. If you buy an insurance policy better to buy it for the most you can do. And I think it's wise to add one percentage point, or say 100 basis points and making very clear that our Core Tier 1 is well above 7%. You are saying is not equity, I am saying is equity because it is as the same treatment of equity and it's not good change that the Bank of Italy considers it a Core Tier 1 facility. We decided that making clear that we are well in excess of 7% sort of eliminate the doubts about our capital adequacy.

We believe that even the risk profile of our bank in the, even in the present situation we would need less than that, but less as this very safe, this very comfortable position for the two, three years that the crisis will last. As far as 2009, I didn't make any figure. I said solid profit because it's really too early to say anything more than that. Everyday, the economic forecast change, so it would be reasonable for me to make any figure. But we expect and we have given the company targets that are consistent with the solid growth concept I used. Please? If there is nobody else here, we can leave to someone else from outside.
Can we leave it? And I will not move until at least a couple of more questions arrive. Maybe the connection has been --.
I'm sorry sir. May I open the Q&A list here?
Please.
Thank you very much. Ladies and gentlemen, the Q&A session for analysts only is open. . First question comes from Mr. Zanardo Marcello from KBW. Mr. Zanardo, please proceed with your question.

. The first question is one second, sorry, maybe you can hear me better. The first question relate on what you have the highest control on in 2009, is probably the most difficult year ever for Italian banks which is cost. If I look at the 3.3% adjusted costs '08 on '07 at the group level, and the 5.1 decrease in Italy, that's done in a year where you still have some investment happening in your Central Eastern Europe network up until I guess September or October. And you said that the investment that you made in 2008 were still at full speed. So my question is I know that you don't want to give more guidance than what you said. But would I be correct to assume in a year where revenues are going to be under significant pressure, at least on adjusted cost reductions similar if not above to what we have seen in 2008, because common sense would imply that? So that's the first question. And the second question is on NII. You've guided to a mid single-digit fall. Would it be possible to detail a little bit more on the hedging or how much hedging is done on the side deposits if you can give us a figure because your rival picked in October, just mid-October, and then it falls 70%, so clearly all liability-sensitive banks will fall a lot and I would expect actually a bigger fall in NII but if you can convince us that your hedging is there at in the market would take it quite positively?

And then finally, more of a general question, listening to your comments and looking at how you are positioning your bank, it implies to me that you're entering 2009 with a quite very pessimistic view because the Bank has a lot of liquidity which are paying. You take a very high level of collateral eligible with the Central Banks. So to me again, I don't want to ask you guidance but if I analyze and adjust this Q4 number of 353 million times four for 2009 taking a 30% cut. I will be very happy for we're running the Bank to close with a net profit just below 1 billion. Is my, without you giving guidance, but is my reasoning correct or is there something wrong in it? Thank you.

Thank you. I agree on what you said at the beginning, 2009 will be the most difficult year also in term, not that much in terms of cost, in general terms. As far as costs are concerned given what we have interrupted from this year in the Central-Eastern European countries. When the repayment? The repayment is totally up to each of the banks. There is no need to wait for others. We will not be blocked or affected by other bank's behavior. Spread, we will not give any guidance on the effect of the hedging facilities we have organized, but for sure from January they will have a visible affect.

Despite the lack of equity of both groups?
Given their situation.

As in practically every industry, you cannot – or at least I don't want to make any statement that holds true for the whole industry.
